docs.snippet: The "CBS Evening News" anchor Katie Couric, a movie buff and huge Colin Firth fan, talks about why she thinks "The King's Speech" will win gold on Sunday night....
docs.lead_paragraph: "You know that one of my favorite movies is 'Malèna'?" Katie Couric said to the Bagger at the start of our conversation. Though she's no cinephile, Ms. Couric, the CBS news anchor, is a self-described movie buff. "My idea of nirvana would be to see like eight movies in one day," she said. Well, filling out our Oscar ballot and talking to us is close enough, right?
docs.abstract: The "CBS Evening News" anchor Katie Couric, a movie buff and huge Colin Firth fan, talks about why she thinks "The King's Speech" will win gold on Sunday night.

headline.main: Oscar Picks, Compliments of Katie Couric

docs.snippet: To lose one parent, Lady Bracknell declares in ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' may be regarded as a misfortune and to lose both looks like carelessness. But the loss of three performers from Roundabout Theater Company's Broadway revival of th...
docs.lead_paragraph: To lose one parent, Lady Bracknell declares in ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' may be regarded as a misfortune and to lose both looks like carelessness. But the loss of three performers from Roundabout Theater Company's Broadway revival of that Oscar Wilde comedy is an inevitability. Though it was recently announced that ''Earnest'' would extend its run at the American Airlines Theater through July 3, the cast members Dana Ivey (who plays Miss Prism), Paxton Whitehead (Rev. Canon Chasuble) and Sara Topham (Gwendolen Fairfax) are set to depart after the March 20 performance. On Wednesday, press representatives for the production announced their replacements: Jayne Houdyshell (whose Broadway credits include ''Wicked'' and ''Bye Bye Birdie'') will join the show as Miss Prism, Brian Murray (''Mary Stuart'') will play the Reverend, and Jessie Austrian (''Lend Me a Tenor'') will portray Gwendolen, all beginning with the March 22 performance. And while Mr. Bunbury makes up his mind whether he will live or die, Brian Bedford, the revival's director, is staying on in the role of Lady Bracknell.
docs.abstract: Cast changes for Roundabout Theater Company's Broadway revival of Oscar Wilde's The Importance of Being Earnest include replacements of Dana Ivey, Paxton Whitehead and Sara Topham. (M)

docs.snippet: 9 P.M. (Fox Business Network) STOSSEL At this point in the awards season you'd have to be living under a rock not to know that George VI -- portrayed by Colin Firth, the best actor Oscar favorite for ''The King's Speech'' -- stuttered. But did you...
docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Fox Business Network) STOSSEL At this point in the awards season you'd have to be living under a rock not to know that George VI -- portrayed by Colin Firth, the best actor Oscar favorite for ''The King's Speech'' -- stuttered. But did you know that John Stossel was also a stutterer? In this edition Mr. Stossel, above, describes how he overcame it. He also looks at the happily-ever-after messages projected by Hollywood movies in general and asks how realistic they are. His guests include Glenn Garvin, the television critic for The Miami Herald; Suzanne Somers, the actress and author of ''Sexy Forever''; Lisa Kennedy Montgomery, a former MTV host; Dr. Paul Offit, chief of the infectious diseases division at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia; and Michael Medved, the radio host and film critic. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA A report on Kate Middleton, the future bride of Prince William.

docs.snippet: The Academy's president won't physically try to stop a disguised Banksy from accepting his reward, and "The King's Speech" shared a location with a gay porn film....
docs.lead_paragraph: Tom Sherak, the president of the Academy, has reneged, sort of, on his earlier comments that Banksy would not be welcome on the Oscars stage. If he shows up to accept an award for directing "Exit Through the Gift Shop," monkey mask and all, "I'm not gonna stand up to stop him," Mr. Sherak told The Hollywood Reporter, adding, "Nobody is, that's not what we do."
docs.abstract: The Academy's president won't physically try to stop a disguised Banksy from accepting his reward, and "The King's Speech" shared a location with a gay porn film.

headline.main: A Banksy About-Face and a 'King's Speech' Coincidence

docs.snippet: Anne Hathaway is the consummate professional, rattling off Oscar show trivia, while James Franco is much more laconic....
docs.lead_paragraph: That Oscars countdown clock over to the right keeps ticking away, and now news about the telecast is coming fast and furious. So far, the producers, Bruce Cohen and Don Mischer, have revealed that to serve their concept of touring Hollywood and Oscar history, they are abandoning most of the movie montages and using an ever-shifting virtual reality set.
docs.abstract: Anne Hathaway is the consummate professional, rattling off Oscar show trivia, while James Franco is much more laconic.

docs.snippet: In the first installment of what will be a monthly fixture, Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer reader questions about the Oscars....
docs.lead_paragraph: In the first installment of what will be a monthly fixture, Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer reader questions about the Oscars. For future columns, they would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.
docs.abstract: In the first installment of what will be a monthly fixture, Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer reader questions about the Oscars.

headline.main: The Critics Answer Your Oscar Questions
